Afterwards'itwas found that a Bill with this object had actually been introduced into the House of Lords under Mr* Bonar IawTsGovernment and had been passed through that House and sentto the Commons.-, In these circumstances the Prime Ministerauthorised me to modify the answer which had been suggestedin the Cabinet, which was no longer appropriate, and it wasgiven in reply to Lord Selborne in the following form :-"aooyOur Lordships will remember that a Bill v/ith this object was passed through your lordships House under Mr? Bonar Lawrs Government in 1923, but was not proceeded with In the Eoi*se of Commons- The matter . has, of course, been under the consideration of the present Government again and the Government hope to propose legislation with the same object without delay, after having carefully considered its terms. I ought to add that, in the present condition of public business, I am not sure that I can hold out any great hope that there will bo sufficient time in tho House of Commons for the Bill to pass through all its stages. So far, however, as this House is concerned, there ought to he no difficulty."The Bill of 1923 is circulated herewith- I suggestit should be in the first instance referred to the HomeAffairs Committee.(Int d. ) S,13th May, 1925* [13 & 14 GrEO. 5.] Honours (Prevention 1of Abuses). [h.l.]a bill intituled an Act for the prevention of abuses in connection ad. 1923. with the Grant of Honours.BE it enacted by the King's most Excellent Majesty, by and with the advice and consent of the Lords Spiritual and Temporal, and Commons, in this present Parliament assembled, and by the authority of the same, 0 as follows : 1. (1) If any person accepts or obtains or agrees to Punishment accept or attempts to obtain from any person, for himself oE touting, or for any other person, or for any purpose, any gift, money or valuable consideration as an inducement or 10 reward for procuring or assisting or endeavouring to procure the grant of a dignity or title of honour to any person, or otherwise in connection with such a grant, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanour.(2) If any person gives, or agrees to give, or offers to 15 any person any gift, money or valuable consideration as an inducement or reward for procuring or assisting or endeavouring to procure the grant of a dignity or title of honour to any person, or otherwise in connection with such a grant, he shall be guilty of a misdemeanour.20 (3) Any person guilty of a misdemeanour under this Act shall be liable on conviction on indictment to imprisonment for a term not exceeding two years or to a line not exceeding five hundred pounds, or to both such imprisonment and such fine, or on summary con-25 viction to imprisonment for a term not exceeding four months or to a fine not exceeding fifty pounds, or to both such imprisonment and such fine.
